> I had a chance to loo=
k at a very interesting tsuba recently. It's a typical
> bird in the plum t=
ree Higo guard, but what's interesting is that it wasn't
> completed. The d=
esign is scribed into the plate and all of the roughing out
> was done with=
 a chisel. Even the outline of the rim is chiseled in with
> multiple cuts =
from both sides. It looks like a slight gouge was used while
> cutting the =
rim and most of the sukashi was cut with a straight chisel.
>
> A couple of=
 sections of sukashi have some file work done, but the rest is
> still roug=
h. It looks like one of the thin branches was chiseled down too
> thin to b=
e finished properly and the piece was abandoned. The color of the
> guard i=
sn't bad (even though I doubt any patina was applied) and the build
> up on=
 the interior sukashi walls looks about like you'd expect for an Edo
> piec=
e.

ce,
